term_definitions.items: Context- or time-specific qualifiers for a specified problem or diagnosis.
This data element is usually recorded as part of a clinical consultation.
Category new, recurring and ongoing issues, problems or diagnoses.
Category that supports division of problems and diagnoses into Active or Inactive problem lists.

The phase is usually determined by a combination of the timing of diagnosis plus availability of supporting test results and clinical advice. It can also imply a level of clinical certainty. Terms aligned with SNOMED CT.
Stage or phase of diagnostic process.
The initial diagnosis made, based on limited available clinical evidence. It may change as test results or advice become available.
Interim diagnosis, based on substantiated clinical evidence but pending further test results or clinical advice. It may still change as test results or advice become available.
Final substantiated diagnosis, based on all relevant test results and clinical advice. It is not expected to change.
The problem or diagnosis is currently active and clinically relevant.
The problem or diagnosis is not completely resolved but is inactive or felt less relevant to the current clinical context.
A first occurrence of a new diagnosis or new occurrence of a previous diagnosis. A flag for 'First ever' occurrence can be recorded separately.
The issue, problem or diagnosis continues, without occurrences of new episodes.
Category that supports division of problems and diagnoses into Current or Past problem lists.
An issue occuring in the past.
An issue which ocurred at present.

In episodic care contexts (commonly secondary care) it is common to categorise/ organise problems according to their relationship to the principal problem or diagnosis being addressed during that episode of care. These categories may also be used for clinical coding, reporting and billing purposes.
The diagnosis determined to be chiefly responsible for occasionaing an episode of admitted patient care, an episode of residential care or an attendance at the health care establishment.
A problem or diagnosis that is occurs at the same time as the primary problem or diagnosis. May also be known as a comorbid condition.
It is not possible to determine if this occurrence of the problem or diagnosis is new or ongoing.
Record as True if this is the first ever occurrence of this problem or diagnosis.
Is this the first ever occurrence of this problem or diagnosis?
Record as True if the problem or diagnosis was present on admission. Used to support identification of in-admission complications among secondary diagnoses that arise during admission.
Was the problem or diagnosis present at admission?
An unfavorable evolution of a problem or diagnosis.
The pattern or evolution of the problem or diagnosis.
A recurring problem or diagnosis, with periods of remission in between.
A problem or diagnosis with persistent or long-lasting effects, or that evolves over time.
A problem or diagnosis with a rapid onset, a short course, or both.

For example: The boolean data type could be used to signify that the problem/diagnosis can be included in a patient summary; the text data type could be used to categorise in a similar way to 'Current?' or Active?'; and the count data type could be used to assert a priority key or order to problems and diagnoses in a list. If any uses are identified as frequently required, they could be added explicitly to this archetype as an explicit data element.
Unspecified qualifier that will be renamed, data type selected and potential value sets specified in a template.
Phase of resolution or healing of an acute problem or diagnosis.
Problem or diagnosis has completed the normal phases of restoration or healing and can be considered resolved.
Problem or diagnosis is progressing satisfactorily through the normal stages of restoration or healing towards resolution.
Problem or diagnosis is not progressing satisfactorily through the normal stages of restoration or healing towards resolution.
It is not possible to determine the resolution or healing status of the problem or diagnosis.

An issue or obstacle which adversely impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual. The definition of a problem is deliberately kept rather loose and inclusive of a formal biomedical diagnosis so as to capture any real or perceived concerns that may adversely affect an individual's wellbeing to any degree.
Identification of the index problem, issue or diagnosis.
The date / time when the problem was first identified by the individual.
The age of the individual when the problem was first identified by the individual.
Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The assessed overall severity of the index problem.
A narrative description of the issue, problem or diagnosis.
Grouping of information about individual occurrences or exacerbations.
The frequency of individual occurrences of the problem.
The date / time of the last occurrence of the problem.
A description of the exacerbation or occurrence.
Number of times this problem has occurred or been apparent.
A group of characteristics of the problem complicating the index problem.
Identification of a related problem as text,coded text or link within the EHR.
The type of relationship that this problem/diagnosis has to the related item.
The date that the problem resolved or went into remission.
The age of the person at the resolution of the problem.
Useful information on the internet about this condition.
Details of the body site concerned.

This concept identifies the direct cause or causative agent of a Problem/Diagnosis. The concept includes the idea of ‘complications’, ‘causative agent’ and ‘due to’. Note: Where no causality or sequence of events is known, this relationship type should be left blank.

This value identifies the sequence of events between the related items, but does not assert causality. This can be used for sequelae or late effects. Note: Where no causality or sequence of events is known, this relationship type should be left blank.
The criteria on which the problem/diagnosis is based.
Clinical stage or grade of a problem/diagnosis. Note: May include formal severity assessments.
A narrative description of the related item.

Descriptor for context- or use-case specific label or workflow-related aspect of the diagnostic process which may not be safe to exchange between systems or use in a shared environment. Examples include: active/inactive; primary/secondary; preliminary/provisional/working/final.
Generic, positive statement/s that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.
Positive statement/s about problems or diagnoses that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.

Use to capture any information that is needed to be positively recorded as being excluded within the record. The statement can support recording global statements or statements about a specified object. See specialisations for Medications, Adverse Reactions, Problem/Diagnosis and Procedures as common examples that have been explicitly modelled.
The statement about an exclusion in the health record.
For example: "No known significant problems or diagnoses"; or "No evidence of" or "Never diagnosed with" (diabetes).
A statement about exclusion of use of known problems or diagnoses in the health record.
Identification of the specific object/s to which the Exclusion Statement applies.
Coding of the Problem or Diagnosis with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Identification of the specific problems/diagnoses to which the Exclusion Statement applies.
The date at which the exclusion was last clinically asserted, affirmed or confirmed.
Additional narrative about the Exclusion not captured in other fields.
Positive statement/s about information that is not available within the health record at a specific point in time.

For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".
Positive statement that no information is available.
The date at which the information was deemed to be absent.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.

items.items: Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.

*An issue or obstacle which adversely impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual. The definition of a problem is deliberately kept rather loose and inclusive of a formal biomedical diagnosis so as to capture any real or perceived concerns that may adversely affect an individual's wellbeing to any degree.(en)

*This concept identifies the direct cause or causative agent of a Problem/Diagnosis. The concept includes the idea of ‘complications’, ‘causative agent’ and ‘due to’. Note: Where no causality or sequence of events is known, this relationship type should be left blank.(en)

*This value identifies the sequence of events between the related items, but does not assert causality. This can be used for sequelae or late effects. Note: Where no causality or sequence of events is known, this relationship type should be left blank.(en)
*The criteria on which the problem/diagnosis is based.(en)
*Clinical stage or grade of a problem/diagnosis. Note: May include formal severity assessments.(en)
*A narrative description of the related item.(en)

*Descriptor for context- or use-case specific label or workflow-related aspect of the diagnostic process which may not be safe to exchange between systems or use in a shared environment. Examples include: active/inactive; primary/secondary; preliminary/provisional/working/final.(en)

default_value.value: No information available about diseases and conditions
